newsitem.title: USA: Vitamins could soften blow of junk-food binge.
newsitem.headline: Vitamins could soften blow of junk-food binge.

text.p: A mega-dose of vitamins taken before a junk-food binge could soften the meal's blow on the body, researchers said on Tuesday.
Cardiologists at the University of Maryland Medical Centre in Baltimore found that blood vessels do not dilate normally after a person takes in a high-fat meal.
But they also learned that taking high doses of vitamins C and E shortly before a double-cheeseburger could prevent the vessels' impairment.

A big fast-food meal "may be affecting our blood vessels even as we eat it," Mary Corretti, an assistant professor of medicine at the university and co-author of the study, said in an interview during the American Heart Association's annual scientific sessions in New Orleans.
The researchers tested 20 healthy adult volunteers who ate a 900-calorie meal of fast-food eggs, sausage and hash browns that was 50 percent saturated fat.
The average blood vessel dilation before the meal was 21 percent.

Two hours after the meal, the volunteers' blood vessels could only dilate an average of 12 percent. "If we repeatedly eat this way I can see we can injure the lining of the blood vessel," Corretti said.
But when the same volunteers took one gram of vitamin C and 800 international units of vitamin E before eating the meal on a different day, the average dilation two hours later was 17 percent.
Corretti was quick to add, however, that she was not recommending that people chew vitamins before an order of large fries, saying the research was still preliminary.
She said the immediate message from the study was the value of a balanced diet, including fruits and vegetables. "It's another argument for eating sensibly," she said.
